p: Hot temperatures have been associated with forms of violence other than collective violence. For example, Nitschke and colleagues ( 49) found that, during heat waves, there was a 13% significant increase in assault-related injuries among people 15–64 years of age. Li and colleagues ( 39) found an association of borderline significance with intentional self-harm (suicide and attempted suicide), with a threshold at 27.2°C (81°F). Page and colleagues ( 53) found that, for each 1°C increase in mean temperature above a threshold of 18°C (64.4°F), there was a 3.8% significant increase in suicide.
